The Government of Pakistan have no objection to the employment by His Highness, of Pakistani subjects as his personal body-guards. 3. The guards, who will be drawn from the Karachi police and will be on deputation to the Kuwait Govern ment, can be seconded to His Highness on the following terms:- (a) Pay at Rs.100 per mensem. (b) The man in charge to be a Havildar on a pay of Rs.150 per mensem. (c) The deputation to be for a period of three years in the first instance. (d) All men would be entitled to leave on full pay every year at the rate of 1/llth of the period of duty. The leave will begin from the date of dis embarkation at Karachi and will end on the date of re-embarkation at Karachi for Kuwait. The leave may be granted to the men in turn or in batches as may be convenient and subject to the maximum admissible at the time. (e) Any member of the body-guard who misbehaves will be liable to reversion without notice and will be dealt with suitably with the Government of Pakistan in accordance with the circumstances of hte case. (f) Free deck passage from Karachi tc Kuwait and back. The guards will also be entitled to once a year to free deck passage from Kuwait to Karachi and back when they proceed on leave. titleInfo.title: 'File 4/37 Kuwait State. Employment of Personal Bodyguard by Sheikh'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence for this description commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 14; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-13; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence between British officials regarding the desire of the Ruler of Kuwait, Shaikh Ahmad al-Jaber al-Sabah, to employ a personal bodyguard force comprised of Pakistani nationals.The British authorities were supportive of the idea and this is expressed in a number of messages exchanged between the Political Agency in Kuwait and other British officials in the region and in Pakistan.The file also contains a list of the terms of employment for the Pakistani nationals being considered for hire that was sent from the Pakistani Ministry of Foreign Affairs to the Persian Gulf Residency in Bahrain (folios 10-11).
